Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Novel CMB Polarization Experiment based on Large Arrays of Coherent Polarimeters
Award.AbstractNarration:
CAREER: A Novel CMB Polarization Experiment based on Large Arrays of Coherent Polarimeters

ABSTRACT

AST 0449809 Amber Miller

Dr. Amber Miller, at Columbia University, will undertake a research program related to the anisotropy in the cosmic microwave background (CMB). The PI will develop a 40 GHz "pathfinder array", to be used for observations of the CMB, and ultimately pave the way for production of a larger-format camera. With this instrument, it should be possible to increase observational sensitivity to polarization anisotropy, and better constrain foreground polarization contaminants. The PI will involve undergraduates in her research. A pilot program, involving a local high school teacher and two students in the PI's research, will also be undertaken - the longer-term goal is to include a student teacher from Columbia's Teacher's College, during each academic year, in the effort.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) consists of a bath of photos emitted when the universe was in its infancy. Because light takes a finite time to travel through space, observations of the distant universe allow us to observe the past, photographing the infant universe. Observations of small intensity variations in the CMB light have led to important cosmological results including, notably, the flat geometry of the universe, the existence of dark energy and dark matter, and a better understanding of the age, the composition, and the curvature of the universe.

New experiments have recently been built to explore polarization of the CMB with the goal of further understanding the details of the physics in the early universe. We are now poised for the most exciting discovery of all. Theory predicts that at the precise moment when our universe was formed, a stochastic background of gravity waves was generated. These gravity waves are far too weak to be detected directly by any upcoming gravitational wave detector but they are expected to leave tiny imprints on the CMB, detectable with polarization-sensitive CMB experiments. The convincing detection of this so-called B-mode polarization is described in the 2010 National Academy of Sciences Decadal Review of Astronomy and Astrophysics as  representing  "a watershed discovery" and this work is identified as high priority science in the coming decade. A detection of this signal would identify the energy scale at which the earliest expansion of the universe took place, revealing fundamental physics at energy scales impossible to achieve in a laboratory, and providing a means by which we can begin to understand where the universe came from, what may have existed prior to the formation of the universe, and the fundamental nature of space-time.

The QUIET Q-band camera built with the support of this CAREER grant is a pathfinder instrument designed to make the most sensitive measurements to date of this polarization signature. This work resulted in a clean meausurement of so-called E-mode polarization in the CMB and our most sensitive look yet at the kinds of contaminating radiation that we are going to need to contend with in order to probe the inflationary gravity waves. This instrument remains the most sensitive one of its kind, and we are currently investigating re-deploying to the Atacama desert for additional observations.

This work also provided valuable training for three postdoctoral scholars, two graduate students, and many undergraduates as well as providing support for the development of a novel program for high school teachers and students from minority and disadvantaged backgrounds in which they spend a summer in the laboratory doing research and finish with a project that takes their work back to the classroom. This high school program continues in our laboratory under the direction of NSF fellow Britt Reichborn-Kjennerud.
